note.body:
@Jehan I don't recall installing any custom brushes, but renaming my `~/.mypaint` directory actually does seem to fix it, so some brushes must have been downloaded automatically I guess at some point by a version of Mypaint.

It does seem weird weird IMHO that GIMP's behaviour/functionality would be dependent on the local hidden directory for a completely different program (`~/.mypaint`) via a common library, though.

There's also a dependency conflict where MyPaint requires a different version of libmypaint than GIMP 2.10 in the Fedora repository. I know this probably isn't the fault of the GIMP developers, but since I'm here, could you point me to where I should go to find out more about this issue?

This is actually my first time in 2.10 as I haven't been able to launch GIMP in a while, so I just gotta say that I'm quite liking the new theming, interface, GEGL features, format support, etc too. I haven't had a chance to play around with it yet, but it's looking like all these new features will bring GIMP back up to par (and then some) with Krita, Blender, etc and in all the areas of my workflow where it was starting to lag behind a bit.

note.body:
I used the system-monitor extension, but the messages above were logged AFTER I disabled all extensions, and even after I disabled gnome-shell itself! It seems that the extension does not terminate completely!
Then I rebooted my machine (with all these disabled), and I had no such log entries.
I enabled the gnome-shell and the unlink and the system-monitor extensions, and STILL I did not have these log entries.
After a few days (and a few suspend/resumes), the log entries started been created again, which, again, only stopped after disabling the system-monitor AND rebooting my machine.
Now I keep the system-monitor disabled, and I have not seen such log entries.
After a few days (with hopefully no such log entries), I plan to re-enable it, to reproduce the problem.

Proposal: GNOME Shell as app
Proposal: GNOME Shell as app

note.body:
Nothing wrong, @lukeblevins15!  
You added one more reason to create Flatpak!  

Another reason: ease of distribution.  
Kubuntu user can easy install GNOME Shell from KDE Discover. So we can promote GNOME Shell and possibly **increase the number of contributors**.  
  
And GNOME fan can easy update to new version of Shell and try first new features.  
  
> Already possible: See `/data/org.gnome.Shell.desktop.in.in` which includes the translatable string `GNOME Shell`. Why do you think that translation is in any way related to "GNOME Shell as app"?

All [GNOME apps](https://wiki.gnome.org/Apps) (Shell at the moment is a [project](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects)) have name translated to all languages. I recommend to translate the name for promote GNOME Shell as app. 

>  An icon only makes sense if an icon is displayed somewhere. Where would an icon be displayed? See https://developer.gnome.org/hig/stable/icons-and-artwork.html for the icon design guidelines.

Icon will be displayed in app stores (GNOME Software, KDE Discover, Flathub).

Eventually, we can improve [GNOME Shell wiki page](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/GnomeShell) and move it to [Apps](https://wiki.gnome.org/Apps) section.

events.target_title: Create app icons according to FreeDesktop specs
Create app icons according to FreeDesktop specs

note.body:
>  Which "some applications" is this about? What's the issue with the KDE Settings icon?

FreeDesktop created in 2005 [icon naming specifications](https://standards.freedesktop.org/icon-naming-spec/icon-naming-spec-latest.html). They explains what icons should be in icon theme and how they should be called.

These specifications offer to create icons and for standard applications.  
Here is the list:

![Снимок_экрана_от_2019-07-29_14-37-40](/uploads/c24399f8d94e82fb7bcb4cebb71335b6/Снимок_экрана_от_2019-07-29_14-37-40.png)  
plus `preferences-system` from categories

GNOME applications come with their own icons (for example, [Nautilus](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/blob/master/data/icons/hicolor/scalable/apps/org.gnome.Nautilus.svg)), but KDE, MATE, LXDE and LXQt apps still use icons from icon themes, not from `hicolor`.

>  What's the issue with the KDE Settings icon?

This concerns not only KDE Settings.
Konsole, MATE Terminal and QTerminal use one icon: `utilities-terminal` from Adwaita icon theme. And so with many other applications.

![Снимок_экрана_от_2019-07-29_14-58-42](/uploads/71614a74e5f25a40b3aa154165245e25/Снимок_экрана_от_2019-07-29_14-58-42.png) ![Снимок_экрана_от_2019-07-29_14-59-00](/uploads/0d2bbaab1b3d8f7e6fda56a86bf66428/Снимок_экрана_от_2019-07-29_14-59-00.png) ![Снимок_экрана_от_2019-07-29_14-58-36](/uploads/cc305c66ab14064b08e8a13e51732160/Снимок_экрана_от_2019-07-29_14-58-36.png)

>  Who is "we" in "We can use"? Which problem would be solved by making icons black and white and how is that related to the problem?

These icons are still in Adwaita, but they haven't been updated to the GNOME 3.32 style and moved to the "[legacy](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/adwaita-icon-theme/tree/master/src/fullcolor/legacy)" folder.

They looks old and don't fit with the new style. We, GNOME, can replace them with icons from our applications, but this will cause confusion, so users can confuse GNOME app with other. Making icons black and white is just one of the suggested solutions.

events.target_title: ssconvert throws warning for formula with brackets

note.body:
So it looks like the original formula was =IF(AND(AC9="Non-Core",AD9="Non-Catalog"),0.25,VLOOKUP(AT9,'file:///home/adam/gitlab/portal/backend/data/2_to_process/Audit Files/Schedule 1 and 2 - 2013 NA_FINAL_2013_08_08.xlsx'#$'Schedule 2-2013 US'.$J$1:$K$1048576,2,0))

After copying it to a file I could share, the formula became: 
=IF(AND(A1="Non-Core",B1="Non-Catalog"),0.25,VLOOKUP(#REF!,[5]'schedule 2-2013 us'!$j$1:$K$1048576,2,0))

But regardless, the last value in the cell was 0.25 and that's all I care about. I'm able to access that value once it has been converted to csv, I just get all these warning messages which aren't really relevant to me since I'm not concerned about the formulas, just the last known value. I want it to process the files as quickly as possible so I don't want it even spending time parsing the formulas when they aren't being recalculated if possible.

[formula_issue.xlsx](/uploads/7d36f1c818724427c69531002b6d574d/formula_issue.xlsx)

The messages I get running this file are:
```
Undefined number format id '43'
Undefined number format id '41'
Undefined number format id '44'
Undefined number format id '42'
Unexpected element 'workbookProtection' in state : 
	workbook
Sheet1!C1 : At C1: 'IF(AND(A1="Non-Core",B1="Non-Catalog"),0.25,VLOOKUP(#REF!,[5]'schedule 2-2013 us'!$j$1:$K$1048576,2,0))' Could not find matching closing quote
```
The warning regarding the quotes repeats for every row that has the same basic formula.

The command I ran was 
`ssconvert -S formula_issue.xlsx temp-%s.csv`

events.target_title: ssconvert throws warning for formula with brackets

note.body:
Thanks. Because my use case requires the conversion to be as fast as possible, I was hoping there was a way to disable the validation of each formula rather than just suppressing the warnings (since that would be less work for it to do and in case other warnings were more relevant) but I'm guessing with how the tool works, that's not easily achieved. I haven't looked into the internals of it at all. 

Thanks for fixing the quoting issue and the suggestion regarding hiding the warnings.

events.target_title: macOS: Popup menu not shown on secondary monitor if it's placed on left of main monitor.
macOS: Popup menu not shown on secondary monitor if it's placed on left of main monitor.

note.body:
There're two bugs in gdk quartz causes this bug.
1. The gdk_quartz_monitor_get_workarea() has a bug that always returns workarea of main monitor.
   It accesses a not assigned value from GdkQuartzMonitor::monitor_num.

2. The GdkMonitor::geometry was set to wrong value.
   It should use coordination based on GdkQuartzScreen::min_x/min_y, but it uses coordination based on main screen's origin.

I already fixed this bug based on 3.24.2.
If that helps, I can post my patch here or fire a pull request.

events.target_title: Unable to reassign F10 shortcut key

note.body:
I have disabled F10 key as global menu hotkey (dconf-editor, org/gnome/desktop/interface/menubar-accel, set it to Custom value and empty string), and successfully reassigned F10 in few applications for custom shortcut (Double Commander file manager, Clementine music player), just to be sure that it works, but in Gimp it still opens first menu, although it was assigned to custom action.

events.target_title: “Open with” context-menu dialog force-sets default application
"Open with other application" will set selected application as default

note.body:
Ok, @antoniof's solution worked like a charm on Arch with Gnome 3.30.2, to set a default PDF viewer, but still be able to occasionally use a PDF editor without changing the default.

> Finally, you can simply open nautilus -> select a folder -> open context menu -> Properties -> "Open With" tab -> select your preferred file manager -> click [Set as Default] button. Done. Now the folder filetype has a (strong) "default application", so it will not fallback to the (weak) "association" with VLC next time.

I'm however confused about this.

> The obvious alternative to the specified ("pick the most-preferred") behavior would be not to pick any app and ask the user to pick it manually instead.

As @antoniof said, it is a bit intrusive to ask the user every time.

From the fix above, it seems that
1. There can be a system-wide default
2. There can be a “strong” user-local default (as set with “Set default” in the file properties)
3. There can be a “weak” user-local default (as set when selecting an application and no other default exists)

The fact that the solution above works, suggests that the current underlying behaviour is as follows (I have checked through the code, but couldn't quite follow where the defaults were set, so this is my best guess). When using “Open with other application”, 
1. If there is a system-wide default, the selected application will only be used this once
2. If there is a strong user-local default, the same as above will happen
3. If there is no default, or only a weak user-local default, the selected application will be used AND set as the weak user-local default.

I am wondering whether there could be a middle ground where, when in situation 3., rather than setting a weak user-local default, a strong one could be set (either by asking the user, or just defaulting to the selected application). As a strong user-local default has now been set, any later actions will be in situation 2., with a known, user-selected default that won't be updated when using “Open with other application”, but can still be changed through “Set as default” in the file preferences.

It seems to me this solution would cater for all scenarios, without adding more user-interaction than necessary (i.e., only the first time, when a default is not already set).

events.target_title: GObject.Value destructor is slow
GObject.Value destructor is slow

note.body: From a reading of the original merge, it seems the fix is related to a misuse of the CPython API to mutate Python objects from another thread without the GIL held. To the best of my knowledge, it is not otherwise possible to cause an object's refcount to incremented from zero to one again, in order for its tp_dealloc to be called a second time on a subsequent decrement, except from within the object's own tp_dealloc.

events.target_title: Systematic crash when trying to open gnome-control-center

note.body:
Hi Benjamin,
good guess, the culprit was NetworkManager. It was not able to start because of connman already running :

```Jan 08 22:30:24 arch-alexis NetworkManager[21772]: <error> [1546983024.0963] bus-manager: fatal failure to acquire D-Bus service "org.freedesktop.NetworkManager" (3). Service already taken```

Disabling connman and replacing it with NetworkManager did the job, I am now able to run g-c-c, thanks a lot

events.target_title: OSK letter disposition does not change when different languages are choosen

note.body:
Hey all et bonsoir à tous,

I just discovered what's wrong here. The French OSK keyboard layout actually uses the "fr-CA" "French Canada" layout, which is a QWERTY layout...

Have a look at the bottom of the fr.json OSK layout file:
[`data/osk-layouts/fr.json`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/blob/master/data/osk-layouts/fr.json)

I had the same problem but with the Swiss French and Swiss German layouts which do not exist yet for the new Gnome OSK nor for the Android OSK which the latter is based on, so the code defaults to the US English layout.

We need to extract the correct French layout and update the **fr.json** file, as well as rename the existing fr.json to **fr-ca.json**.

I'll happily take care of that at the same time I add the Swiss French and Swiss German layouts later this week.

Cheers,

JL

note.body:
I do not know. From what I see the letter or lowercase with an accent is an Extended ASCII character.

DEC243 OCT 363 HEX F3 BIN 11110011 Symbol ó HTML Number ó HTML Name ó Description Latin small letter o with acute

I only inform you about the problem I found and how I could solve it. 
However, it does not want other factors do not influence. I already had in the past, problems with installers in windows with the letter ñ. It is possible that the latest update of Windows 10 has some problem in this area. I do not know.
Additionally, I had problems with other software (StarryNight Pro 7) that after performing the complete installation, I ended up deleting the executable file. After changing the path to non-problematic characters everything worked perfectly.
I hope my information is useful.
A greeting.

events.target_title: Redesign the file selection dialog
Redesign the file selection dialog

note.body:
Emmanuele, if you want to ignore just my complaints, that's fine; and if it means that you will react to the comments of all the other users that complained, I'd very happy about that. I didn't understand your comment "Leaving comments in this bug is pointless." as you would. And I guess no one else did. 

But you're right, I'll try to be constructive instead of just complaining:

There were some good points in the bugzilla thread like the last comment: "If there is problem with same named folders just print their partial path. If someone named them the same way they clearly had reasons and I do not see that it is gtkfilechooserwidget place to save them from confusion." Very good point I think. 
And also consider that the moment you click on one of the "recent" folders, you will see the full breadcrumb path above it (at least in the GTK2 dialog). So even if someone had three identitcally named folders in the recent list (how likely is that???), he could easily identify them by clicking them all once and check the breadcrumb path and would immediately know which one was the desired one. And using the breadcrumb path he could even navigate back, or after clicking on the recent entry he could select subfolders etc.

So let's check the "issues" that you claim must be solved (from [https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=751653](here):

1)  "it's almost impossible to identify any of the folders you see listed there."

No, it isn't. First, you usually haven't a bunch of identically named folders, have you? Can you give an example where this makes sense AND you use all of them for saving within a short time window so that they all appear in the recent list? And if they have different names, you will know which folders you see them. If there is a folder "photos" you will remember what this folder is as you obviously used it short before and not think "photos? What? I have a folder names photos? Where the heck is that folder on my hard disk?"

Second, if you really can't remember what folder you see there, click on it and check the breadcrumb path and you have exactly identified it.

2) "Directories are nested, and you travel through them to get to other directories (typically they are steps in a path, rather than a destination). They don't make sense when seen outside of their tree."

If that was true, bookmarks wouldn't make sense, too. Even the home folder which is still visible in the GTK3 file dialog wouldn't make sense, it's just a folder, too, and you see it outside it's tree (which isn't neccessarily just /, could also be /mnt/cip/m/<username> for all users starting with m. That's how it works here for students in our computer rooms. So unless you plan to remove bookmarks, too, a recent folders list is just a list of temporary bookmarks. And with these bookmarks you can jump to certain locations in the tree and continue to navigate.

What's the difference between jumping to the home directory and continue to travel through the directories, or jump to the "photos" bookmark and travel through it's subfolders, or jump to "march_2018" in the recent folders, click on the "photos" breadcrumb above and then select "april_2018" because you saved the last photo in march_2018 and want to save the next one in april_2018?

The moment you click on one of the directories in the recent list, you are in the tree (via the breadcrumb path). The only difference is that you didn't start in the home folder but in some subdirectory. As is for bookmarks.

So this argument doesn't make any sense unless you forbid bookmarks and let the user start in "/" every time so that he will have to travel all the way through the directories mnt -> cip -> m -> marc before he can start to select anything in his subdirectory.

3) "It still isn't clear to me how the order of the folders is determined - it says it is sorted by Modified, but the listed directories haven't been changed themselves. ... (and more rhetorical questions)"

It's really clear how the directories are listed, and it is not inconsistent with the two  bugs that Allan mentions. Because those relate to recent files, not directories. And it makes a lot of sense to me to sort "recently used filed" by the time they were used, e.g. loaded without being changed, while a list of directories that were recently used for "saving" of course can be seen and sorted in a different way! Why should it be inconsistent to sort loaded files by access time and directories used for saving by mtime? It's not inconsistent, it makes perfect sense! Because a directory is modified if you store a file into it, so what's wrong with mtime here?

The only little glitch is this: when you copy a file to a directory (our just touch it) that was in the recent list, it will move up. So the gtk file dialog will show the list of recently used directories that were used in the save dialog, but in the order those directories were altered from anywhere. I.e., if I save to "a/", then "b/", then "c/" in firefox, and then touch a/, the recent list will be in order "a,c,b" instead of "c,b,a". 

So that's the only thing that could be confusing: that the order of the directories can differ from the order you used them with the save dialog. 

The main problems in Allans bug report seems to be this:
"When saving, I regularly get confused by the recent view. It's different from the recent view in files and when opening a file, which I am familiar with. This means that I often have a moment of incomprehension when I see it. Also, it's almost impossible to identify any of the folders you see listed there."

But so far, and the thread on bugzilla.gnome.org isn't the only place where people asked for the missing recent list, it seems that no one else is sharing Allans confusion. And I really don't understand how one can be confused by this. You see a list of the directories you have been using during your last saving actions!

No one in the bugzilla thread seemed to be confused about this. I'm working as system administrator for a chair at a university, so I did ask a bunch of researchers and students before writing here if they had ever used recent list when saving files. Of those who did (about 3/4), no one had any problem using it or understanding how it works. They never realized that the order could have changed a little bit, not even when I showed them it was possible. All they said about that was "Ok, but I still see my (number from 3-20) directories that I mostly use".  And those who hadn't used the recent directories it before mainly said "Oh, cool, I didn't know I could do that".

So even if one would see some real issue somewhere and not just Allans confusion: it seems to be an issue that almost no user has ever been hit by. But many users are unhappy that the recent list is gone, including all of those who used it at our chair. Most of them didn't realize  yet that the recent list had gone because there are still many programs using the GTK2 save dialog here.

So let's discuss 1) - 3) if my arguments are wrong. If they are convincing, I'd be happy if you could consider bringing the recent folders back for the save dialog.

events.target_title: Remove only RAW images from RAW+JPEG pair

note.body:
Yes, I think this would definitely fit with the workflow of many photographers who shoot in RAW+JPG, but want to discard most of the RAW files at some point, only to keep those JPG files and a few RAW files that will be edited.

On the other hand, you also have people shooting in RAW+JPG in order to have a JPG file as a temporary reference for developing (editing) the RAW file and who will want to discard the JPG files at some point, then only keeping the RAW files.

Option 1:

So, I think that what should be implemented is a menu item for each RAW+JPG pair, to either drop the RAW file *or* the JPG file. Then, the dropped file would go to the Shotwell trash bin. If the file in the Shotwell trash bin is recovered by the user, then the RAW+JPG pair would be reconstituted, with the same tags as the ones included in the file that was not dropped (i.e. that was kept in the database). 

Option 2:

As an alternative, the solution could also be to do like in daktable (see: https://www.darktable.org/usermanual/en/image_grouping.html) and Lightroom (see: http://lifeafterphotoshop.com/lightroom-raw-plus-jpeg-pairs/) and allow the user to choose if he/she wants to group (pair) or not the RAW and JPG files, which means that when the RAW and the JPG files are *not* grouped (paired), an action (like deletion or tagging) on one file should have no impact on the other. My understanding is that you can already achieve such a result in Shotwell, but in a complicated manner, i.e.  you have to import the files in 2 different steps, so the JPG file is not imported at the same time than the RAW file. If I'm not mistaken, it seems that in such cases, Shotwell will not pair the 2 files.

I'm not a developer, but my guess is that Option 1 would be easier to implement in Shotwell and maybe more easy to manage/understand for the user.

events.target_title: Allow multiple autoconnected VPNs (list of checkboxes)

note.body:
Workaround for cli via https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/NetworkManager/NetworkManager/issues/36

```
You can use nmcli to set multiple secondaries is this way:

nmcli connection modify 'Wired connection 1' connection.secondaries UUID1,UUID2,UUID3

where UUID* are the UUIDs of VPNs that can be found with nmcli connection.
```

events.target_title: Adding exponentially smoothed curve to chart  compromised gnumeric file integrity

note.body:
OK, errors reproduction is pretty elaborate. Seems to be a combination of the exponentially smoothed curve and the way I used an if...then with edate function.

I checked following possibilities in attached file:

1. set cell F3="" -> crash
2. set cell F10=NULL and then F3="" -> no crash
3. erase exponentially smoothed curve from chart und set cell F3="" -> no crash
4. erase exponentially smoothed curve from chart, set cell F3="" and add exponentially curve again -> crash

[error.gnumeric](/uploads/4c7a11c1fd13341e1b6c13865dc6b98c/error.gnumeric)

Please give answer if this can be verified by someone else.

events.target_title: Poor contrast with dark theme active

note.body:
The problem is in the `adwaita.css` file that's shipped with Calendar: it uses the `theme_fg_color` in the `event-light` class but that's a bright color for adwaita-dark (and probably other dark color schemes).

The easiest fix is to use `black` as color and call it a day.

events.target_title: GIMP crashes when i scanned a photo at 1200dpi.fine with 800dpi
GIMP crashes when i scanned a photo at 1200dpi.fine with 800dpi
Ctrl+F search (inside a page): if the search entry is already visible but not focused, pressing Ctrl+F a second time doesn't change the focus to the search entry
Connection status indication
Fatal error upon opening GIMP

note.body:
I had the same problem. Looking at the console output I could see, that GIMP had problems to load a specific font. Thus, the splash screen did show only empty rectangles instead of proper startup information.

Now, that I have installed the "Dejavu Sans" font everything works fine and the exception does not occur anymore.

You can download the font here: https://www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/DejaVu-Sans

BR

events.target_title: GLib.MainContext().query() is crippled and unusable

note.body:
@creiter I want to integrate the GLib main loop into the Python one https://docs.python.org/3/library/asyncio-eventloop.html, in order to utilize the `async`-`await` syntax sugar.

BTW, it is impossible to create custon `GInputStream` via the current Python binding, because the first argument to [`do_read_async`](https://lazka.github.io/pgi-docs/#Gio-2.0/classes/InputStream.html#Gio.InputStream.do_read_async) is an immutable `bytes` object. A mutable `bytearray` should solve this problem.

events.target_title: Should only ask for password as a direct result of user action

note.body:
I frequently get the 'Authentication is required to update software' popups on Silverblue as well.
Another report I found while trying to search for information on how to resolve this:
https://distrowatch.com/weekly.php?issue=20181112

(see the section starting with "The one thing I didn’t like about rpm-ostree is that it presented me with tens of "Authentication is required to update software"")

I think what is happening is that Gnome is trying to check as the logged in user if updates are available in order to give the user a prompt to install them -- and the password request occurs at the start of the update check process.

I get the same exact prompt when doing a non-root update check:

```
[user@silverblue ~]$ rpm-ostree upgrade --check
(popup occurs here, which I clicked cancel on)
error: rpmostreed OS operation AutomaticUpdateTrigger not allowed for user
```

Annoyingly, you'll often have a large number of these prompts stacked on top of one another, and you'll have to cancel like 5 times in a row.

I would be more than happy to disable these automatic update checks so that I can perform them myself manually, but I haven't found anywhere in GNOME that I can do that.

If anyone knows a workaround, it would be appreciated.

How to reproduce:

1. Install `Dynamic Panel Transparency` extension.
2. Launch a not GTK application like Firefox or Chromium but not gedit or Nautilus.
3. Maximize the application and close the window or unmaximize it and  press `Ctrl+L` immediately.
4. `gnome-shell` is crashed.

You can find the extension issue [here](https://github.com/rockon999/dynamic-panel-transparency/issues/108).

events.target_title: ‘cannot open source to write’ when importing, but number is imported anyway

note.body:
I have found out what the problem is.
In the migration from computer to computer, from Windows to Linux, from Banshee to Amarok etc. etc. some files are stored twice: once as Author/song.ogg (or flac or whatever) and once as Author/Album/song.ogg.  Rhythmbox imports the first one (whichever is discovered first) following its own settings, then tries to create the same file again and barfs.  So I guess this is a RFE: give a more detailed error message in this case.

events.target_title: ‘cannot open source to write’ when importing, but number is imported anyway

note.body: Interestingly, if I just copy over the entire Author-folder (so with some files directly in the directory, others below an Album subdirectory) to the music folder, RB discovers them and simply shows the file twice in the overview.  So no importing or conversion is done in that case.  Another RFE maybe: detect and remove duplicate songs (probably in a plugin).

events.target_title: ‘cannot open source to write’ when importing, but number is imported anyway

In short: if I import, I want RB to detect which files are already in the library.

events.target_title: "Open with other application" dialog with Wine shows many duplicate entries
"Open with other application" dialog with Wine shows many duplicate entries

note.body:
Gtk is 3.24.1

Grep makes things clear, this is one entry for each mime type Wine wants to register (if I had more Wine prefixes this would probably multiply).

```
$ grep -R "A Wine application" /usr/share/applications/ ~/.local/share/applications/
/home/stu/.local/share/applications/wine-extension-swf.desktop:Name=A Wine application
/home/stu/.local/share/applications/wine-extension-midi.desktop:Name=A Wine application
/home/stu/.local/share/applications/wine-extension-mp2.desktop:Name=A Wine application
/home/stu/.local/share/applications/wine-extension-flv.desktop:Name=A Wine application
[snipped]
```

Krita is the same
```
$ grep -R "Krita" /usr/share/applications/ ~/.local/share/applications | grep uk
/usr/share/applications/krita_heif.desktop:Name[uk]=Krita
/usr/share/applications/krita_jpeg.desktop:Name[uk]=Krita
/usr/share/applications/krita_raw.desktop:Name[uk]=Krita
/usr/share/applications/krita_png.desktop:Name[uk]=Krita
[snipped]
```

I've attached a file with the Krita and Wine desktop files (should just be Winamp, MS Office and a few other bits).

[krita_and_wine_deskto_files.tar.gz](/uploads/325983d293426e4885b18c19a67e2af3/krita_and_wine_deskto_files.tar.gz)


There are different things happening with Krita and Wine, with Krita being more straightforward:


The Krita desktop shortcuts look like this
```
cat /usr/share/applications/krita_gif.desktop                                         
[Desktop Entry]
Name=Krita
[snipped translated names]
Exec=krita %f
MimeType=image/gif;
Type=Application
Icon=calligrakrita
Categories=Qt;KDE;Office;Graphics;
StartupNotify=true
NoDisplay=true
```

The ```Exec``` line is always ```krita %f``` only the mimetype seems to change.

Could the GUI de-dupe these or would it cause issues elsewhere ?



The Wine entries look like this:

```
$ cat /home/stu/.local/share/applications/wine-extension-mp3.desktop
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Name=A Wine application
MimeType=audio/mpeg;
Exec=env WINEPREFIX="/home/stu/.wine" wine-development start /ProgIDOpen Winamp.File.MP3 %f
NoDisplay=true
StartupNotify=true
```

```
$ cat /home/stu/.local/share/applications/wine-extension-compositefont.desktop 
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Name=A Wine application
MimeType=application/x-wine-extension-compositefont;
Exec=env WINEPREFIX="/home/stu/.wine" /opt/wine-staging/bin/wine start /ProgIDOpen Windows.CompositeFont %f
NoDisplay=true
StartupNotify=true
```

The ```Exec``` line includes information about the file association so is always different.

I'm not sure what could be done here, apart from Wine having more descriptive ```Name``` entries ?

events.target_title: "Open with other application" dialog with Wine shows many duplicate entries

note.body:
Thanks for looking at this.

I've opened a bug for Krita
https://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=403194

This old Wine patch attempts to group associations by program, I'll see if it still applies
https://bugs.winehq.org/show_bug.cgi?id=25166

From the conversation there it looks like Wine has to work around a mismatch whereby fd.o desktop files deal with mimetypes, whereas windows works on file extensions.

Closing as this doesn't seem to be a Gtk issue.

events.target_title: Evince always open in display 1 on Ubuntu 18.04 under X
Evince always open in display 1 on Ubuntu 18.04 under X

note.body:
All other applications open in display 2 when launched from display 2. Same for applications launched in display 1, they open in display 1 correctly sized. 

For example, if I move a terminal window from display 2 to display 1 (or open a terminal window in display 1), and then launch firefox, the browser window opens correctly in display 1. If I launch evince from the terminal window in display 1, the Recent Documents window opens in display 2, not display 1. 

I did not open a ticket on System76 or Ubuntu, as this is the only application in my Ubuntu installation I have come across that displays this abnormal behavior. This includes apps from the Ubuntu repositories and paid for third party apps (eg wing ide)

It took awhile (3-5 weeks) for me to discover this behavior in evince after installing Ubuntu 18.04. I normally just use display 2 and display 1 is dark. Every time I tried to launch evince the window never appeared. I thought it might be broken in Ubuntu 18.04, so just stopped using it and waited for a couple of updates/upgrades to fix the problem. One day, I happened to look at display 1, and there were the evince windows I had tried to open, but huge without any title bars so I could drag them to display 2. 

Mark

Mouse pointer size on screens with high resolution
Mouse pointer size on screens with high resolution

note.body:
I think my first description was not very good. My problem is that the settings for screen scaling in gnome are very limited. I have a 15,4 inch notebook with 4k (and and a second 27 inch monitor with 4k) and everyting is very small with 100%. With 200% scaling 4k is useless. So, depending on screen size I would need something like 175% for my notebook (on 17 inch it would be something like 150%) and on the second monitor 125% would be optimal. As this is not possible, i'm scaling the font size but this is just a compromise (the size on my notebook is a little bit to small, on the second screen it is to big but that's the only solution at the moment I know). Unfortunately the mouse pointer doesn't scale with the font but with the screen which is not scaled but still at 100%. But the mouse pointer is ok on my second screen, but on a notebook screen it is really hard to find it sometimes. 
So in my opinion it is time to take new screen densities into account as more and more monitors have higher resolutions. For me, the best solution would be to add 125%, 150%, 175% to the screen scaling options.

I'm currently running on Xorg.

This is not a bug but a feature request.

According to https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-directory-thumbnailer/blob/master/src/main.c#L308 , it tries to locate the thumbnail or generate it. That raises the question if that logic is applicable **inside** of a `bwrap`ed environment.

Using the following custom thumbnailer
```sh

TryExec=echo

MimeType=inode/directory;
```

events.target_title: How to add keyboard shortcut for a Nautilus.MenuProvider

note.body:
If your question is simply about opening a certain application with a keyboard shortcut, you can use a Nautilus Scripts for that and assign a keyboard shortcut to that script.

First, you create a small launcher script in `~/.local/share/nautilus/scripts`, see here https://help.ubuntu.com/community/NautilusScriptsHowto

Then, you create a script accels file in `~/.config/nautilus/scripts-accels` to assign a keyboard shortcut to your script.

Unfortunately, this approach (currently) does not work when searching due to this bug https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/788

thumbnailer: Correctly cleanup stale thumbnailer directories

note.body:
I wanted to emphasize the fact that a file having no extension is a perfectly reasonable result. Returning `NULL` suggests something went wrong in the computation.

Also, this change makes the `get_extension` function more intuitive by making it behave like functions that compute the extension of a file in other programming languages (I used Python's `os.path.splitext` as a reference https://docs.python.org/2/library/os.path.html#os.path.splitext).

One argument to keep returning `NULL` is, preventing breakage when this function is used outside of `gnome-desktop-thumbnail-script`. However, as we can see in this PR `get_extension` is a very customized function that is tailored to be used inside `gnome-desktop-thumbnail-script`. Also, I could not find any traces from it be used outside here.

I would prefer to keep it returning `""` but no strong opinion on that. What do you think?

note.body:
While I agree it would be nice if gnome-tweaks could provide a setting for that, having a limit to 30s without much information for end-user on how to change it is IMO a bad default value.
I've been trying to use it multiple times in the past and never understood there was such limit and thought it was a bug; so I installed other softwares like EasyScreenCast. These days, EasyScreenCast isn't working anymore and latest gnome-shell so I'm back to try Gnome screencast and am facing this issue again. I thought it was still the same bug and spent 20 minutes doing some research before finding this ticket and the related solution tweaking dbus.
All that would have been more straightforward if there weren't such limitaiton by default: I'd never have searched for alternatives, never installed EasyScreenCast, never faced its bug in latest Fedora, never spent 20 min finding the reason why my video stops without me deciding it to stop...

Please consider setting the default to unlimited.

note.body:
> Perhaps it being too easy to not remember/notice you started a screencast, and fill up the destination with video?

That can be one reason, but this case of file getting too big should be computed more dynamically according to free space or some other heuristic than pseudo-hardcoding 30 seconds.
And in case we're reaching this limit, a notification warning would be fine.
About remembering/noticing the screenshot, just changing the icon to a stronger color could help.

events.target_title: screencast stops in 30 seconds

note.body:
As a first iteration, I'd be in favor of removing the limit ( https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-settings-daemon/merge_requests/73 ) and then wait for some people who face disk space issue or other to report their story so some relevant smartness can more easily be implemented.
Maybe this will reveal that some other resource (RAM, CPU/GPU availability) is a more important constraint; and maybe we'll also see that Gnome already does good work at notifying users when hard drive gets crowded so no extra notification strategy is necesary.

events.target_title: screencast stops in 30 seconds

note.body: Frankly, if you go for keeping such a low and unrealistic limit for actual decent usage out of the box, you might as well kill the porject, remove from Gnome by default and move the related effort for EasyScreenCast.

Offer OpenStreetMap as an alternative tiles layer to MapBox

note.body:
Yes, you are correct in that the tiles are under a CC license.

However, third party software such as GNOME Maps should not use the OSM tile server as stated in their [Tile Usage Policy](https://operations.osmfoundation.org/policies/tiles/) as OSM is entirely funded by donations.   
Maps is using a "community API key" from MapBox (see the [NEWS on 3.21.4](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-maps/blob/gnome-3-30/NEWS#L1044)). That sounds to me like there's no cost involved in using MapBox tiles for Maps. I was pretty surprised by how outdated the tiles are, though. I set up a tile server with the MapBox Light style for my company and updating OSM data isn't too hard, so I don't see why they're delivering old tiles.

note.body:
Hi. On @mlundblad 's advice, I took up this bug (or feature). If the `street_name` is available for any two points, I'm taking the first and that one from last which is not blank (i.e. ""). I initially tried it out with taking the `street_name` for the first and the 2nd last point (since the last is always Arrival Point and has no `street_name`), but there were places where the route file name made complete sense if I considered the first non-blank street_name from last of `turnPoints` array. 

I also had make little changes here and there to `GraphHopper` and `TurnPoint` class since I couldn't figure out a way to get the street_names any other way. 

For the fallback case, when no `street_names` are present for the whole route, for taking the latitude and longitude of the route starting point and route end point, I had to add a small getter to `GraphHopper` class. I think there is some property somewhere, but I couldn't find it. Any help would be appreciated. 

Thanks in advance. Elated on working on my first bug. :)

events.target_title: 2.58.2: Assorted asserts fail in Arch Linux when built statically

note.body:
AFAIK Arch doesn't use separate -dev pacakges but includes the dev files (like headers) in the library package itself.

I'm working on a patch to get the tests working for the static builds. For me the failing tests are: `appinfo`, `desktop-app-info`, `giomodule` and `resources`. After some debugging, it turns out that the failures of `appinfo` and `desktop-app-info` are caused by incorrect permission settings on my local machine so we can just ignore it, and the failures of `giomodule` and `resources` are caused by usage of `.so` based modules. After tweaking the build scripts (like `gmodule/meson.build`) to set `g_module_impl` to `0`, `resources` is fixed, but `giomodule` doesn't respect that configuration, so `gio/tests/giomodule.c` should be modified to check `g_module_supported()` before testing.

events.target_title: Fix tests failures for static builds

note.body: @nirbheek You're right. I just figured out that `GModule` it self isn't the root cause of the problem. What actually makes the tests fail is the combination of `GModule` and `GIOExtensionPoint`. When statically compiled, the test binary and plugin module are linked with their own copies of `GLib` respectively, so calling the functions of `GIOExtensionPoint` in the plugin module actually has no effect on the copy linked with the test binary.

events.target_title: UI font becomes black
UI font becomes black

note.body: I found this bug in all 2.10.x versions.

events.target_title: File export options dialog slow to appear

note.body: Ok, now I can understand why the speed was increased - there were 1516 items in the folder. So when I moved those files in the backup, my Gimp opens file dialog very quickly. Maybe when Gimp shows Export File Dialog, it tries to read a lot of useless information from those files?

events.target_title: "Open as layer" from command line
"Open as layer" from command line

note.body:
> With `gimp foo.jpg --as-layer bar.jpg --as-layer baz.jpg` it makes sense to add `bar.jpg` and `baz.jpg` in whatever image was created from `foo.jpg`. I would even prefer a simpler syntax such as `gimp --as-layers [file] [file]` since this would allow things like `gimp --as-layers frame-*.png`

I agree.

I also agree on your second point, however, I'm sure there **is already** a workaround.
>  But if you do gimp --as-layer image.jpg and have foo1.jpg and foo2.jpg already loaded as different images, or even worse opened foo.jpg twice, to which image should the layer be added?

There is one 'active' image. The new layer will be added to that one. It's the same as if you have multiple open images and press "File"->"Open As Layers...". It also will add the layer to the active image.

>  And then consider the case of multiple Gimp instances...

What happens if you have multiple gimp instances and you exec `$ gimp foo.jpg`? Which instance does it chose? I don't know because I'm not able to open two instances. 
I don't know why; perhaps gimp prevents this actively?

$ pacman -S mingw64/mingw-w64-x86_64-gtk3

$ pacman -Sl | grep gtk3
mingw32 mingw-w64-i686-gtk3 3.24.3-1
mingw32 mingw-w64-i686-webkitgtk3 2.4.11-6
mingw64 mingw-w64-x86_64-gtk3 3.24.3-1 [installed]
mingw64 mingw-w64-x86_64-webkitgtk3 2.4.11-6
```

I can confirm, that this issue is duplicate of the #1544.

note.body:
When running with with GDK_SYNCHRONIZE=1:

```
(moo:14684): Gdk-ERROR **: 14:06:25.384: The program 'moo' received an X Window System error.
This probably reflects a bug in the program.
The error was 'BadValue (integer parameter out of range for operation)'.
  (Details: serial 365 error_code 2 request_code 53 (core protocol) minor_code 0)
  (Note to programmers: normally, X errors are reported asynchronously;
   that is, you will receive the error a while after causing it.
   To debug your program, run it with the GDK_SYNCHRONIZE environment
   variable to change this behavior. You can then get a meaningful
   backtrace from your debugger if you break on the gdk_x_error() function.)
```

I tried running it under gdb with the appropriate breakpoint set, but it apparently still skipped right past the breakpoint and ran right through to SIGTRAP.  I still have the resulting corefile (6MB compressed), with a substantially similar backtrace.

events.target_title: test_overrides_gdk:test_cursor() causes SIGTRAP under Xvfb

note.body:
One more detail that may be of interest: this problem only seems to occur if I have Xvfb running in 8-bit color depth.  In 16-bit or 24-bit color depth, this problem does not occur.  (FYI Debian's xvfb-run launch-wrapper defaults to 640x480x8.)

So that makes this rather less severe.  Maybe it's just something to do with 8-bit/palettized vidmodes?  Does anyone even use such vidmodes anymore?

note.body:
@csoriano I think this issue has merit. This is about the double-click on folder, not the Enter key.

Right now, if you use Ctrl/Shift+Enter key, it works as documented.

However, while double clicking a folder, doesn't work as expected:
Ctrl+Double-click opens in a new tab.
Shift+Double-click also opens in a new tab, while one would expect a new window.
